awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Guiding future design of affect-aware cyber-human systems through the investigation of human reactions to machine errors
awd_abstract_narration:
This project obtains new fundamental knowledge about how people react to errors made by affect-aware technologies. Such technologies analyze measurements such as heart rate, brain activity and body gestures to obtain an estimate of a user's mental and emotional state; they then take actions to improve the user's state - for example, by helping with a task. However, since the measurements are often hard to interpret, affect-aware technologies often make mistakes. Led by an interdisciplinary group of researchers in engineering and psychology, this project will examine how users react to and compensate for different types of errors made by affect-aware technologies. This will help guide future design of such technologies, as it will help researchers and developers identify what the minimal acceptable accuracy of an affect-aware device is and what types of errors most critically need to be reduced by developers. Results of the research will advance national health and well-being in many ways, as affect-aware technologies are becoming increasingly common for diverse applications such as detecting drowsiness in drivers, adaptive automation in flight and resource management, adaptation of learning material to students, and adaptation of rehabilitation exercises to patients. The team will develop new interdisciplinary courses in human factors and human-computer interaction, and will perform outreach about cyber-human systems to multiple groups including K-12 and community college students and teachers all around Wyoming.

The project is structured as a series of four lab studies involving human subjects, all using a set of physiological sensors and the NASA Multi-Attribute Task Battery. As little is known about user reactions to machine errors in affect-aware cyber-human systems, the first three lab studies will systematically vary four critical characteristics: the accuracy with which they recognize the user's psychological state, the magnitude of the actions (changes to task difficulty) taken by the system, the impact that an error has on task performance, and the transparency of the system's decision-making process. The errors will be induced with a Wizard of Oz experiment design in which, unknown to the subject, the machine responses are actually simulated by a human operator. In this project, the user will be asked how they would like to change the difficulty of the Multi-Attribute Task Battery, and errors will be induced by doing the opposite of what the user wants. Users will be unaware of this manipulation, and will be told that the errors are actually due to poor signal processing and pattern recognition. The last study will then examine the trade-off between a system's state recognition accuracy and its user-friendliness with regard to user acceptance of the system. In all four studies, the outcome measures will be objective task performance as well as subjective user experience reported with the NASA Task Load Index and Intrinsic Motivation Inventory. This will provide the research community with detailed information about how different characteristics of affect-aware cyber-human systems influence both objective and subjective aspects of users' experiences with such systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on affect-aware technologies, which use diverse sensors to measure a human user's psychological state and then adapt the behavior of the technology in order to bring the user into a more desirable psychological state. For example, a computer game may automatically change its difficulty in order to keep the user entertained, or an airplane autopilot may automatically activate if the pilot is too tired to focus. However, computers cannot always perfectly recognize the user's psychological state, and cannot always perfectly adapt their behavior in response to the recognized state. The goal of this project was thus to examine how human users react to mistakes made by affect-aware technologies. All research was performed in the context of a scenario that adapts task difficulty in response to user psychological state, and we focused on four research questions:

- How does the accuracy of psychological state recognition and task adaptation influence the user experience with affect-aware technology? In a study with 112 human subjects, we showed that user experience generally improves as the recognition/adaptation accuracy increases, and we were able to quantify how much a certain increase in accuracy was likely to improve different aspects of user experience. We also showed that these effects vary slightly depending on the amount of adaptation done by the machine.

- How does the impact of the errors made by the affect-aware technology influence user experience? In a study with 97 human subjects, we compared situations where the technology makes noncritical, easy-to-correct errors vs. situations where the technology makes critical irreversible errors. We found that users are less tolerant of lower recognition and adaptation accuracies when the impact of a machine error is high. Furthermore, participants' reactions were different when the machine made errors that resulted in boredom than when it made errors that resulted in the user being overwhelmed.

- How does the degree of insight into the technology's decision-making process influence user experience? In a study with 93 human subjects, we showed that users are more tolerant of errors made by the machine if they are provided with an understanding of why these errors were made.

- How do the technology's obtrusiveness and setup time influence user experience? We conducted a study that compared a convenient and comfortable technology to an uncomfortable technology that was time-consuming to apply. However, we were surprisingly unable to show differences in user experience between these two devices. We posited that this was due to a suboptimal study protocol where each participant only experienced one technology, and suggested potential future studies that may better evaluate this effect. 

While many of these results may seem intuitive, they had not yet been systematically quantified in affect-aware human-computer interaction. Designers of affect-aware technologies will be able to use the results of the project to determine which aspects of their technologies to focus on, optimizing the development process and leading to better outcomes. Evaluators of affect-aware systems will be able to use our results as a benchmark of whether a system is performing well enough to result in a positive user experience, and will be able to adapt our own methodology to their own application areas. Additionally, affective computing researchers will be able to use our findings as a basis for studying other aspects of affect-aware systems, and will (if desired) be able to use our open-source software as a basis for such studies. Finally, the findings of the project are likely to impact adjacent human-computer interaction disciplines where studying user reactions to machine errors is important.

In addition to the main research work, our team contributed to several research studies on affective technologies and clinical psychology. Additionally, the project included several education and outreach activities. The hardware purchased for the project was used to perform lab sessions and capstone projects in both undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Cincinnati and University of Wyoming. Lectures about the project were given in multiple courses at both institutions, and the investigators gave in-person and virtual presentations about the project to elementary school, high school and community college students from various Wyoming and Ohio schools. Finally, the project provided one-on-one training to several graduate students. The project has thus been highly productive with regard to scientific impact, potential broader impact, and education and outreach.
